lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Like HTML + CSS, we can use the style property to style specific elements inline without using a dedicated CSS file.

We can do the same in React.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Unlike in HTML, the style property doesn't expect a string but an object.

Ensure the style property receives an object inside the embedded expression.

Make sure to pick style, followed by {}.

lessons.title: b
lessons.interactiveContent:
We pass an object that includes the styling rules. In this case, none.

Note the {{ and }} is a combination of a JSX expression and an object.

Make sure to pick { followed by { and then }, }.

lessons.title: c
lessons.interactiveContent:
The rules are defined as an object with key-value pairs.

Set the color of the button to "green".

Make sure to pick color, followed by :, and finally "green".

lessons.title: c - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to add multiple rules, we separate them by comma.

Remember, this is a JavaScript object, as you have seen and used many times before.

Make sure to pick ,.

lessons.title: c - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Since we use a JavaScript object, we use camel case instead of hyphens.

Make sure to pick background, followed by Color.

lessons.title: c - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also define the object first and pass a reference to the style property.

Make sure to pick buttonStyle, followed by buttonStyle.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Style the button color to red using the style property in React.

Make sure to pick color, followed by :, and finally "red".

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following demonstrates setting the text color to purple in a React component?

style={{ color: "purple" }}style="color: purple"

style={{ color: "purple" }}.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a paragraph style object and apply it to the paragraph text.

Make sure to pick paragraphStyle, followed by paragraphStyle.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is true about React inline styling?

Styles are passed as objects using camelCase propertiesStyles are defined as strings

Styles are passed as objects using camelCase properties.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Modify the button to have a yellow background and bold text.

Make sure to pick { followed by backgroundColor and then "bold", }.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
How would you define a button's background color and font size using React's style property?

style={{ backgroundColor: "pink", fontSize: "16px" }}style="background-color: pink, font-size: 16px"

style={{ backgroundColor: "pink", fontSize: "16px" }}.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Apply an inline style to a div to have a border and padding.

Make sure to pick style followed by = and then {, {, }, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement about React inline styling is correct?

Styles are passed as JavaScript objectsStyles can be defined using an array

Styles are passed as JavaScript objects.
